facts.text: Land Acquisition Act, 1894 was amended by the Land Acquisition (Madhya Pradesh Amendment) Act, 1959 (Madhya Pradesh Act V of 1959), hereinafter referred to as the impugned Act.
By section 3 of the impugned Act, after clause (g) of Sec. 3 of the Act of 1894, a new clause was added defining 'Bhopal area'.

A new section 17A was inserted in the Land Acquisition Act, 1894, giving to the Government the power to issue a direction to the Collector that it is urgently necessary to acquire immediate possession of any building site situated in Bhopal area, and providing that upon the issue of such a direction the provisions of Sec. 17 would in all respects apply in the case of such site as they apply in the case of waste or arable land.

A new proviso was added to the first clause of Sec. 23(1): 'Provided that when the market-value of any land situate in Bhopal area, in respect of which the date of publication of the notification aforesaid is after the commencement of the Land Acquisition (Madhya Pradesh Amendment) Act, 1957 (21 of 1958), is in excess of its market-value as on the 1st day of October, 1955, the market-value thereof shall be deemed to be its market-value as on the 1st day of October, 1955.'

A new sub-section (3) was inserted in S. 23 enjoining the Court to award a further sum not exceeding twenty five per cent of the market-value of the land acquired and an additional sum provided under sub-sec. (2), as the Court may think fit, in consideration of the appreciation in the price of the land concerned by reason of the location of the capital at Bhopal, regard being had to the situation of such land.
Notification to acquire the land in question under s. 4(1) of the Land Acquisition Act, 1894, was published in the Madhya Pradesh Rajpatra, dated October 3, 1962.
Notification under s. 6(1) of the said Act was published in the Madhya Pradesh Rajpatra dated November 23, 1962.
Notice under S. 9(1) was published for general information and notices under s. 9(3) were issued to the individual interested parties.

Land Acquisition Officer gave his award in the Land Acquisition Case No. 51/LA/62 on March 25, 1969. The award was given on the basis of market value of the land as on October 1, 1955 plus 25 extra compensation, and not on the basis of the market value of the land on or about the date of acquisition, by virtue of the provisions of S. 3 of the Land Acquisition (M.P. Amendment) Act, 1959.
Bhopal was made Capital of Madhya Pradesh on November 1, 1956.

States Reorganisation Commission report, 1956, submitted on September 30, 1955, recommended Jabalpur as the capital: 'Jabalpur will be situated at a central place in this unit and has or will soon have some important facilities like water supply and availability of electrical power. It will, in our opinion, be a suitable capital.'
In Satish Kumar v. State of M.P., the Madhya Pradesh High Court upheld the validity of the impugned Act.
Counter affidavit by State in para 21 denies that the Amendment Act infringes Article 14.

legal_issues.text: Whether the impugned Land Acquisition (Madhya Pradesh Amendment) Act, 1959 violates Article 14 of the Constitution as there is no rational classification on the basis of which the prices of Bhopal area have been determined differently from other places.
Whether the date October 1, 1955 is arbitrary for fixing the market value.
Whether there can be rational basis to differentiate between Bhopal and other areas for award of compensation merely because Bhopal was made Capital.

petitioner_arguments.text: Impugned Act violates Art. 14 as there is no rational classification on the basis of which the prices of Bhopal area have been determined by the principle by which the market prices of other places would be determined.

There can be no rational basis to differentiate between Bhopal and other areas for award of compensation merely because Bhopal was made Capital. The theory that in view of Capital, there was speculative prices at Bhopal and the prices at any given time might not reflect the real price, is neither rational nor reasonable.
The date, October 1, 1955, is an arbitrary date for the purpose of fixing the market value.

respondent_arguments.text: Denies that the Amendment Act infringes Article 14.

In the reorganisation of the States, which was a political exigency, the fixation of the Capital at Bhopal was an accident not due to any economic or industrial reasons; when it was decided to locate the Capital of the State in the underdeveloped town, there was heavy speculation in land prices and therefore these artificially inflated prices could not be taken as a proper basis for fixing the real market-value of the property.

Whenever a capital or a big industry is located in a town, land values are suddenly pushed up by prospective sellers and the increase during the interregnum between the date when it is known that the town will become more important and the date of acquisition may not represent its real value. Prospect of acquisition gives rise to speculative dealings; it is not unreasonable to compute market-value with reference to a date proximate to exclude speculative rise.

court_reasoning.text: Learned Advocate General was unable to point out any material to show that there was any expectation or speculation on or about the 1st October, 1955 that Bhopal would be the Capital of Madhya Pradesh. If this fact had been established, it may have been reasonable to have fixed the date for the purpose of determining the market value as 1st October 1955.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No material showing speculation on 1 Oct 1955.

court_reasoning.text: On the material on record, it is impossible to hold that there has been a discrimination in the matter of compensation between land acquired in Bhopal area and other areas in the State. The classification between land in Bhopal area and other parts of the State is with reason and reasonable, and is for the purpose of enabling the State to acquire land at a reasonable price in Bhopal for the construction of the Capital.
In our view, the amendments are not hit by Article 14 of the Constitution.

With respect, the High Court has not examined the question of the validity of the reason for fixing the relevant date as October 1, 1955. There is no material on the record to show that on October 1, 1955, it was known that Bhopal may be the Capital of the State or that there was speculation in land because of this fact.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court failed to examine date validity.

holdings.text: The impugned amendments are not hit by Article 14 of the Constitution.
Classification between Bhopal area and other areas is reasonable for enabling State to acquire land at reasonable price.

precedents_cited.relevance: Same principles of law applied; petition heard along with it.

precedents_cited.case_name: Satish Kumar v. State of M.P.
precedents_cited.relevance: MP High Court upheld Act but did not examine validity of fixing date as 1 Oct 1955.

outcome.summary: The petition challenges the validity of the Land Acquisition (MP Amendment) Act 1959 under Art 14. Court holds amendments do not violate Art 14, classification reasonable, no material for speculation on 1 Oct 1955; applies principles from Civil Appeal No. 2139/1968.
